What nobody mentions here is that the center of mass of the slinky still falls at 9.8 m/s2 (i.e. it is free falling with the acceleration of gravity), which means that, to compensate for the bottom coils not falling, the top coils are falling much faster than what they would if you just cut the top few coils and dropped them alone. An the reason is simple: The same tension that is pulling up on the bottom coils cancelling the force of gravity, is pulling down on the top coils adding to the force of gravity.

But there's two waves going through, not just one. There's a slight, subtle narrowing of the gap between coils that precedes the "domino" collapse of coils hitting each other, and this seems to be linked to the twist.

This less dramatic motion is the standard behaviour of a spring on the release of tension, and the reason for the more dramatic "domino" is surely just that the slinky has so little springiness that other factors make the spring equation less significant to the overall motion.

Kind of a bad explanation at least for me, I found it easier to understand when u think of the slinky horizontal already on the ground. If you stretch it out and let it go, it will contract with both sides contracting into the center. Then if you hold the slinky in the air, it gets stretched (by gravity), you let go and it contracts, both sides contract at once. The bottom side contracts upwards, the top side contracts downwards. The reason the bottom side doesn’t seem to move is because at the same time as it contracts upwards, it is pulled down by gravity. Eventually the slinky closes and the bottom doesn’t want to go up anymore, so gravity takes over and it starts falling.

I think this phenomenon falsifies Newton's theory of gravity and is empirical evidence that gravity is an energy field.
The stretched out slinky is a result of you holding it and reaisting gravity. This creates potential energy in the slinky. When you let the slinky go, the energy is released and the mass begins to accelerate downward, but at the same time as the potential energy in the slinky is released. Because of conservation of energy, the slinky resists falling to a lower level of energy until its excess energy is burned up, but this potential energy that held the slinky at its energy level is now kenetic energy and so the overall acceleration is still equal to that of a slinky that had no potential energy stored, which means it should hit the ground at the same time as a slinky dropped from the lowest part of the slinky. The gravitational delay will be countered by an increased initial acceleration once the potential energy is gone (the slinky is collapsed again).
That's my theory anyhow, but i think it shows that mass isn't attracting mass, but instead that mass is interacting with an energy field that accelerates mass downward.

For brainless person like me, this is the simple terms to explain it.

Place the slinky horizontally at the floor. Then ask your friend to hold one end, and you hold the other. Your friend hand, act as gravity that pull slinky

When you release the slinky, only your end that go towards your friend hand. The other side of slinky also tried to go to your side, but it can't do that because the gravity hold it. So it doesn't move anywhere

If we neglect gravity (which means that your friend also release it at the same time), then the slinky will collide at the middle

This is awesome! This reminds me of a conversation between my brother and I about rope when we were younger. He said that if you had a rope that reached all the way to the moon and pulled on it, it would be a faster means of communicating by morse code than using waves(e.g. radio). But I countered him and told him that when you pull on something, it acts like a spring, at a molecular level. So you pulling on something acts like a wave, where you pulling the initial part will then eventually pull the atoms next to it. I don't know what speed would dictate rope being pulled, I'm assuming it has to do with molecular spring coefficients, but I think it would still be slower than any EM frequency.

This is because the initially when you hold  the slinky from one end and other end exert a gravitational force . According to Newtowns third law  "every action has equal and opposite reaction" so the tension force create in slinky forcing upward against gravity . When you drop the first end  , it fall down but due to "innertia of rest"   bottom end remain in rest until the all the tension force stored in the slinky is not released.

This is wrong. Gravity is a constant based on mass. The stored energy by holding the top of the slinky is equal to gravity pulling on the mass of the slinky when he releases the slinky the stored energy is released but what looks like a floating bottom is really the coil contracting (collapsing) toward the center of the slinky but the slinky is falling at the same rate as the energy released upward toward the center creating the illusion of a floating bottom of the slinky. If it wasn’t then the slinky would fall to the ground unchanged before the coil contracted.

The rotation is caused by the UNtwisting of the wire. This causes the whole slinky twist clockwise or counterclockwise, depending on the coil twist. You can see such effect when you hang a weight on a string and let it oscillate: the weight starts to rotate clock and counterclockwise. To counteract this effect, we use a spring made of two halves, each coils in opposite direction.

I think its important to mention that all objects fall this way
the differnce for everyday objects, is usually its an atomic process

but if u drop a piece if wood, all the atoms at the top will drop before the ones at the bottom, for exactly the same reason
wood is just too stiff for u to notice

if u had a stick of wood, 1 light year long, and u push an end
people typically think the other end of the stick would move simultaneously
but much like the slinky, there is a limited speed to the propagation of movement
in everyday matter, it is roughly equivalent to the speed of sound

so u push the stick, it will compress, and that compression will propagate towards the other end of the stick
causing movement
all matter works that way

Curious you are looking for a wave to explain the twisting, when it is the lack of compression which causes that twisting.  It occurs as soon as the top is released, because the distance the wire travels between the same spot on two coils becomes shorter, until they touch.  This forces the wire to push down its length, following the rigid form of its substance.  This creates a rotational force that is related to the rigidity of the substance of the coil.  This is why the plastic slinky is more unstable, as it allows the coils to expand out and deform more that its metal counterparts. I wonder, if Sir Isaac Newton had access to a slinky, would he have worked out relativity? When I think about this effect from an Einsteinian perspective, it seems far less mysterious (even if special relativity is still mind-bending). Before its release, the top of the slinky is being pulled, accelerated in fact, at a rate of about 10m/s², against its natural geodesic path downward. Each molecule of the slinky pulls on the next and eventually, the whole slinky is accelerating. When the slinky is released, the top is no longer accelerating and molecule by molecule, the acceleration stops, and because of it's unusual shape and springiness, this re-contraction is visible to us.

We ourselves are like springs that are being contracted by being accelerated upwards. We don't really notice this acceleration because we feel it constantly, but in fact when we are at rest, we are all being accelerated upward, away from our natural geodesic path to fall downward. When that force is released and we find ourselves in free fall (like when an elevator going upward reaches the top or a roller coaster goes over a "hill"), we feel our bodies uncompress. I wonder how fast a slow-motion camera would have to be in order to see the decompression wave of someone standing on a platform that was suddenly removed from beneath them and they started falling. Their feet would start to fall slightly before their head and it would be possible to see a decompression wave move from their feet to their head, much the same way as with the slinky. I'm not sure if it was this channel or vsauce, but a similar concept explained there pretty much blew my mind:
Suppose you construct a metal rod that is 1 light year long, and place a button about 6 inches from the end of it. If you stand at the far end from the button and push the rod those 6 inches, you might think that pushing this rod would "instantly" press the button on the other end because through observation of very short rods (like a 1 foot rod for example), this is how it appears. As such, you'd perhaps think that you have thus moved faster than light to press the button on the other end. However, it doesn't work like this, and the rod you pushed at this end will take a very long time to transfer that force over it's length to the other end. Its crazy for me to think about, but the rod will visibly move on this end, while the other end will remain where it is until this compression force has time to pass from one end of the rod to the other. The compression force is basically a wave that travels at the speed of sound over the given material, so depending on the material of the rod if could take 50,000 years for the button to be pressed on the other end! Note that a rod like this would both be impossible to build, and impossible to push.

I'm not an expert (in high school)but here's my version:
the spring tension is equal to the gravitational pull for the bottom but since there is no upward force on the top,the top falls down, decreasing the spring tension which happens to always be opposing gravity in an equal manner for the bottom.
The bottom always feels an upward pull provided by the tension to cancel gravity and the excess tension energy left over after cancelling gravity is used to accelerate the top part even more. That's why the top part is accelerating downwards slightly faster than gravity.
When the top reaches the bottom,there is no spring force left to cancel gravity and the bottom also starts falling like a looney toon.
As for the spinning part, this maybe due to slight increase in diameter of slinky when is compresses. The diameter increases a bit and the slinky rotates like a reverse screw.

Do Correct me if I'm wrong or if you want to add anything.

This is a good example of how gravity works across space too.

Or more specifically, the inverse. Gravity is a tension against...kinetic energy I guess, and that's kind of a static state until external change influences it. But the propagation of that change is limited by the speed of light. Although funnily, the limit is only local. The speed of light a light year away isn't specifically the speed of light here. Light from each star is traveling at the speed of light relative to itself, but at any observation point, the speed of light constant. There's a relative dynamic compression/expansion happening to equal out the observed result. I know there's some stuff discussed about this, like the red shift/blue shift doppler effect of perceived wave length, but I don't think I've ever once seen any discussion related to mass particles.

I've never once seen anyone, ever, discuss this...which seems weird.

Cool demonstration. The reason the bottom doesn't fall at first is because of Newton's 2nd law. For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. The spring is pulling itself back together. That means the bottom part is pulling on the top parts. So even though the top is falling (and it cannot fall any faster than gravity)  - the bottom is trying to pull itself up so it appears motionless.

The way I like to think of it is that the information involved is traveling at a limited speed. Because the slinky isn't a rigid object it takes time for the top of the slinky to communicate to the bottom of the slinky that it is no longer being held up (I suppose technically the same is true of rigid objects as well, but information travels through them much faster). Until the compression wave reaches it there is just no way for the bottom of the slinky to "know" that it is no longer being held up against gravity.

It proves gravity is not an attraction of masses, otherwise the whole slinky would fall when released. The reason why the top falls and the bottom stays in place when released is because the bottom ring of the slinky was supported by the force of the slinky rings above when held up. When released, all the force holding the bottom ring up has to be zero force before the bottom ring falls. If gravity was an attraction of masses, the entire mass of the slinky would start accelerating towards the ground when released. But it doesn't!

The twisting wave comes from the asymmetry of the collapse itself. If it slightly bends up in a direction that is not perfectly axial it results in a twist that starts at the top and travels down below, which of course can be seen at the bottom. The bigger the slinky the the greater the artifacts you bring in the collapse mode resulting in more twisting.
We call it the "Wile E. Coyote Effect"

I believe this to be innacurate, at least in the way it's described in this video. If you extend a slinky lateraly and release its ends at the same time what will happen? Both ends contract to the centre if the slinky with a force that is equal to the mechanical force stored in its coils by the extention. When a slinky dangles by its own weight, the force stored is equal to the "force" of gravity pulling it down. So when we release the top end of the slinky both ends start to accelerate towards the centre of mass with acceleration proportional to the force stored. So the upwards acceleration of the bottom end due to the force stored is equal to the downwards acceleration due to gravity, hence it remains roughly immobile. But if you take the centre of mass which is in the middle of the slinky, it starts "falling" (or accelerating towards the Earth) at the moment of release. Maybe im wrong though, this is just my gut instinct talking.
